curriculumAlignment.outcomeDescription: Chemical change involves substances reacting to form new substances
elaborations: Identifying the differences between chemical and physical changes
Identifying evidence that a chemical change has taken place
Investigating simple reactions such as combining elements to make a compound
Recognising that the chemical properties of a substance will affect its use
Investigating chemical reactions employed by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples

keyConcepts.name: Physical vs chemical changes
keyConcepts.description: Physical changes alter appearance but not composition; chemical changes form new substances

keyConcepts.name: Signs of chemical reactions
keyConcepts.description: Observable evidence: colour change, gas production, precipitate, temperature change, light/sound

keyConcepts.name: Reactants and products
keyConcepts.description: Substances that react (reactants) combine or break apart to form new substances (products)

keyConcepts.name: Word equations
keyConcepts.description: Representing reactions using names: reactants â†’ products

keyConcepts.name: Combustion reactions
keyConcepts.description: Rapid reactions with oxygen producing heat and light; fuels burn to form carbon dioxide and water

keyConcepts.name: Oxidation and corrosion
keyConcepts.description: Slower reactions with oxygen; rusting of iron forms iron oxide over time

keyConcepts.name: Conservation of mass
keyConcepts.description: Total mass of reactants equals total mass of products; atoms rearrange but are not created or destroyed

keyConcepts.name: Types of reactions
keyConcepts.description: Synthesis, decomposition, combustion, and other reaction types have predictable patterns

keyConcepts.name: Energy in reactions
keyConcepts.description: Exothermic reactions release energy; endothermic reactions absorb energy

keyConcepts.name: Reaction rates
keyConcepts.description: Factors affecting speed: temperature, concentration, surface area, catalysts

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Dissolving is a chemical reaction because the substance disappears
commonMisconceptions.correction: Dissolving is a physical change - the substance spreads out but its particles remain unchanged; it can be recovered by evaporation

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Melting and boiling are chemical changes because the substance looks different
commonMisconceptions.correction: Changes of state are physical changes - the same molecules exist before and after, only their arrangement changes
commonMisconceptions.source: Ahtee and Varjola, 1998; RSC Chemical Misconceptions

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Atoms can be destroyed or created during a chemical reaction
commonMisconceptions.correction: Atoms are never created or destroyed in chemical reactions - they are only rearranged to form new substances

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Mass is lost when something burns because it gets lighter
commonMisconceptions.correction: Mass is conserved - gases (CO2, H2O vapour) escape into the air; if measured in a closed system, mass stays the same

commonMisconceptions.misconception: All chemical reactions need flames or fire to occur
commonMisconceptions.correction: Many chemical reactions occur without flames - rusting, digestion, photosynthesis, and baking soda reactions all happen without fire

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Chemical reactions happen because atoms want full outer electron shells
commonMisconceptions.correction: Atoms don't 'want' anything - reactions occur when the products are more stable (lower energy) than the reactants

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Rusting only happens when iron is wet
commonMisconceptions.correction: Rusting requires both oxygen AND water; iron in dry air or in water without oxygen does not rust

commonMisconceptions.misconception: The bubbles in boiling water are made of hydrogen and oxygen (the water is breaking apart)
commonMisconceptions.correction: Bubbles in boiling water are water vapour (steam) - a physical change; water molecules stay intact

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Only the total number of atoms matters for conservation, not the types
commonMisconceptions.correction: Conservation of mass requires the same number of EACH type of atom on both sides - not just the total count

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Exothermic reactions are always explosive or violent
commonMisconceptions.correction: Many exothermic reactions are slow and gentle - hand warmers, composting, and rusting all release heat slowly

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Products of a reaction have the same properties as the reactants
commonMisconceptions.correction: Products are entirely new substances with different properties - sodium (explosive metal) + chlorine (toxic gas) = table salt

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Catalysts are used up in reactions because they make reactions faster
commonMisconceptions.correction: Catalysts speed up reactions but are not consumed - they can be recovered unchanged after the reaction

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Striking a match and watching it burn
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: What makes a match burst into flame with just a quick scratch?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Rusty car parts or outdoor furniture
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why does metal turn orange-brown and crumbly when left outside?
Where do all those bubbles come from when you mix baking soda and vinegar?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Cooking an egg - white turning solid
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Why can't you 'uncook' an egg even if you cool it down?
What creates the air bubbles that make bread fluffy and light?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Glow sticks at concerts and parties
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How does bending a plastic tube create light without electricity or heat?
Why does a fresh apple slice turn brown within minutes?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Great Barrier Reef coral bleaching and ocean acidification
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How is carbon dioxide in the air dissolving coral reefs in the ocean?
How did First Nations peoples use fire to create chemicals that made medicines more effective?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander science, cultural heritage

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Fireworks display on Australia Day or New Year's Eve
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How do different chemicals create all those different colours in fireworks?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Hand warmers for cold sports games
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: How does shaking a little packet produce heat that lasts for hours?

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Car exhaust fumes and air pollution
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: What exactly comes out of a car's exhaust pipe and why is it harmful?

scaffoldingSequence.name: Distinguish Change Types
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Identifying physical vs chemical changes through observable evidence

scaffoldingSequence.name: Understand Reactions
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Reactants, products, word equations, and simple reaction types

scaffoldingSequence.name: Apply Conservation
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Conservation of mass, oxidation/corrosion, and reaction types

scaffoldingSequence.name: Extend and Apply
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Energy changes, reaction rates, complex applications

cognitiveLoadNotes: Start with familiar everyday examples before introducing chemical terminology
Use demonstrations and videos to show reactions - reduces need for mental visualization
Keep word equations simple initially; avoid symbol equations until concepts are solid
Use compare/contrast tables for physical vs chemical changes
engagementStrategies: Begin with 'magic' demonstrations (colour changes, gas production) to create curiosity
Allow predictions before revealing what happens - builds investment in learning
Use cooking analogies - students understand that cooking changes food permanently
Connect to fire safety and bushfire awareness for Australian relevance
motivationFactors: Connect to cooking and food science
Link to environmental issues (coral bleaching, pollution)
Relate to forensic science and crime investigation
Include Aboriginal science and cultural knowledge
desirableDifficulties: Interleave physical and chemical change examples to improve discrimination
Include retrieval practice on earlier concepts (particle model, states of matter)
Vary contexts between everyday, laboratory, and environmental scenarios
testingEffectOpportunities: Classify examples as physical or chemical change
Write word equations for given scenarios
Explain conservation of mass in different reaction contexts

questionDesignGuidelines.mcqDistractorStrategy: Use documented misconceptions as distractors (e.g., 'dissolving is a chemical change', 'atoms are destroyed')
questionDesignGuidelines.shortAnswerFocus: Require explanation of WHY a change is chemical, citing evidence; explain conservation of mass
questionDesignGuidelines.diagramQuestions: Include before/after particle diagrams showing atom rearrangement
questionDesignGuidelines.calculationOpportunities: Simple mass conservation calculations (mass of reactants = mass of products)
questionDesignGuidelines.realWorldApplication: At least 50% of questions should use real-world contexts (cooking, rusting, burning, environment)

supportStrategies: Provide evidence checklist for identifying chemical reactions
Use sentence starters for word equations
Break conservation of mass into visual step-by-step examples
Use graphic organizers for reaction types
extensionOpportunities: Investigate factors affecting reaction rates quantitatively

crossTopicConnections.connection: Particle model explains why chemical reactions involve atom rearrangement
Understanding elements and compounds is prerequisite for understanding reactions
Energy transformations during reactions connect to broader energy concepts
